newsitem.title: USA: Clinton delays key Cuba sanction provision.
newsitem.headline: Clinton delays key Cuba sanction provision.

text.p: President Bill Clinton on Friday ordered a further six-month delay in implementing a controversial provision in a law imposing sanctions on Cuba that has angered U.S. allies.
Clinton indicated he was willing to continue suspending the controversial provision as long as the international community applied pressure to bring democracy to Cuba.

In a statement issued in the U.S. Virgin Islands, where he was vacationing, Clinton said: "Today, in order to consolidate and build on the momentum we have generated for democratic change in Cuba, I have decided to extend for another six months" a provision that would allow U.S. citizens and companies to sue anyone using their property seized in Cuba's 1959 Communist revolution."

The provision in the so-called Helms-Burton law was passed in early 1996 after Cuban jet fighters shot down two unarmed U.S. civilian aircraft flying off the Cuban coast in international airspace. In July, Clinton delayed implementing the controversial provision for an initial six months while the United States reviewed protests from countries which said it violated the rights of their citizens.

"I would expect to continue suspending the right to file suit so long as America's friends and allies continue their stepped-up efforts to promote a transition to democracy in Cuba," Clinton said in his statement.
